abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second School Access and
            Improvement Project for Djibouti were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory; risk to development outcome
            was moderate; Bank performance was moderately satisfactory
            and borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned includes: where the project scope is
            limited, project development objectives and indicators
            should be specific and measurable. The establishment of a
            monitoring and evaluation system depends on having
            sufficient capacity within the borrower's institutions
            as well as borrower ownership. Strong coordination with
            donors during preparation and implementation is essential to
            identify financing gaps and optimize interventions in the
            sector, as well as increasing efficiency. Where the borrower
            has limited capacity in bank procedures, extensive support
            is required. The large investments in school infrastructure
            underline the need for a strong maintenance unit to
            implement the maintenance strategy. It is important to link
            training with career development. The growing demand from
            parents to enroll children with special needs requires a
            longer-term strategy to be put in place to consolidate the
            efforts achieved so far in this area.
